properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: suppression of a large armed mob who had taken lists relating to the Supplementary Militia from some of the constables on their way to Bakewell
properties.Results: The magistrates draw attention to the need for further protection on the days of ballot and attestation, and in pursuing the ringleaders of the riot and in taking evidence from witnesses. [Folio 309 not used].
properties.Label: Bakewell, England

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: events at Biggleswade when the militia men to be provided by the three Hundreds of Clifton, Wixatree and Biggleswade were to be chosen by lot and requesting that he 'may receive instructions how to act in an affair of this delicate nature'.
properties.Results: I must however, in justice, to the rest, and far the greatest part of this county, observe to you, that though the raising of the militia in the manner chalked out by the present Bill seems unpalatable to many, yet I have not in any part of it where I have been, observed the least disposition to riot or disloyalty'.
properties.Label: Biggleswade, England

properties.Name: Knowles Riot / Impressment Riot
properties.Agents: protest against navy impressment
properties.Label: Boston, Province of Massachusetts Bay

properties.Name: Boston Massacre
properties.Agents: anti-British / patriot riot
properties.Results: resulting in military intervention
properties.Label: Boston, Province of Massachusetts Bay

properties.Name: Bridgwater Army Riots
properties.Agents: riot at Bridgwater on June 10, involving men in Brigadier Honeywoods' Regiment, Thomas Howes, Scrivener, John Hallway, dragoon, Charles Goodall, dragoon, [blank] Aighton, quarter master, John Hellin, and Thomas D[ip]on, sergeant. Names mentioned are: Colonel Hamilton, and Jonathan Thomas.
properties.Label: Bridgwater, England

properties.Name: Impressment riot
properties.Agents: riot at Cockbridge against the swearing and enrolling of ballotted men and substitutes for the [Supplementary] Militia. [The magistrates] had begun the proceedings when the rioters forced their way into the room armed with bludgeons, protesting against any swearing in of militia. Mr Knubley, a fellow magistrate who had put on his hat, was violently struck on the head with a bludgeon, but this was the only violent act they received. The rioters took all the papers and the new testament and burned them on the fire after which they deemed they had done enough, although drinking and confusion prevailed. The landlord advised that the magistrates should forego their dinner there for their own safety and the safety of the house as he had heard that they planned further mischief, and so the magistrates left by horse. Saunderson, the [window tax] surveyor, did not heed the advice and remained. He was rolled in the mud by the rioters and obliged to give them two barrels of ale and made to promise he would charge no more horses to duty. Mr Blennerhassett, High Constable, was also hunted down and would have suffered severely had not some taken pity on him and let him escape. The chief protagonists in this riot were from Bassenthwaite.
properties.Results: The rioters returned in the late evening when the surveyor was at dinner and forced their way in. A young woman tried to hinder their progress and was thrown over the banisters. She was not injured but caught by people below. Upwards of 400 people were involved but the mischief was perpetrated by about 25, the rest looking passively on. Most of the rioters are known but not all. Satterthwaite states that the swearing in and enrolling at Whitehaven had been adjourned to a later date.
properties.Label: Cockbridge, England

properties.Name: Militia Law Riot
properties.Agents: riot on 1 April 1795: The riot was caused by constables serving notices of the execution of the Militia Law (reference also to opposition to the 'Act for raising Land and Seamen') to all the parishes instead of 'some few'.
properties.Results: 2 collective petitions on behalf of John Williams and Robert Roberts, convicted (together with Edward Jones, John Jones and Hugh Davis; sentences are: Edward Jones, 4 years imprisonment; John Jones 4 years imprisonment and Hugh Davis, 3 years imprisonment) at the Great Sessions for Denbighshire at Ruthin
properties.Label: Denbighshire, England

properties.Name: Durham Riot
properties.Agents: opposition to the new ballotting system for militia recruitment
properties.Label: Durham, England

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: riot at the swearing in of the militia at the Rose and Crown at Elham, 2 July 1759
properties.Label: Elham, England
properties.Archival sources: Kent History and Library Centre U269/O308

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: riot of pressed men on the vessel "Endeavour"
properties.Results: Recommend he is reimbursed and quote a precedent when Thomas Braggett, Master of the Batchelor's Delight Tender received compensation for the loss of his boat in which pressed men had escaped in May 1736 and Richard Ashby, Master of the Page Tender was allowed money for making good damage caused by pressed men in April 1740.
properties.Label: England
properties.Archival sources: National Maritime Museum: The Caird Library, Manuscripts Section ADM 354/113/232

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: seeking the Home Secretary's approval of his action in placing a division of the Honourable Artillery Company, numbering about 30, under arms every evening to protect the Armoury House and its neighbourhood, as the Riot Act had been read in Finsbury Square on 16 July and in view of the present state of the Metropolis
properties.Label: Finsbury Square, London, England

properties.Name: Riot in response to the killing of Robert Park
properties.Agents: local riot caused by the killing of Robert Park by Sergeant Davies
properties.Results: investigation by Lord Advocate Stewart
properties.Label: Glasgow, Scotland

properties.Name: Riots against the Militia Act
properties.Agents: At Epiph. Sessions, 1758: many indictments for riots against the Militia Act and for burning militia rolls.
properties.Results: The following is an example of the form of Indictment: 'Gloucester To witt The Jurors for our Lord the King upon their oath present that Henry Barrow late of Rodborough in the County aforesaid labourer and Anne his wife the thirtyeth day of August in the seventh yeare of the reign of his present Majesty King George the Second with force and arms and so forth at Chaffenage [Chavenage] in the county aforesaid one Hempen Sheet of the value of two shillings and sixpence of the goods and chattells of Richard Stephens Esquire then and there found then and there did feloniously steal take and carry away against the peace of our said present Lord the King his Crown and Dignity Pleads not guilty, the Jury say that they are both guilty to the value of 6d.'
properties.Label: Gloucester, England

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: riot in pressing at Greenock on 13th November 1760
properties.Results: several men apprehended and committed to gaol
properties.Label: Greenock, England
properties.Archival sources: National Maritime Museum: The Caird Library, Manuscripts Section ADM 354/169/176

properties.Name: Henley Riot
properties.Agents: riot at Henley upon Thames between bargemen, townspeople and soldiers quartered there; examinations taken of seven men in Col. Fleming's Regiment. Thomas Newell to John Sharpe that he considers the riot to be a quarrel between the soldiers and some drunken men in the town.
properties.Results: Edward Weston to the Mayor of Henley upon Thames giving detailed instructions for an enquiry into the riot there [see f. 133]. Two additional Companies of Foot are to be quartered in the town.
properties.Label: Henley, England

properties.Name: Hexham Riot
properties.Agents: riot against new militia regulations
properties.Label: Hexham, Yorkshire
properties.Archival sources: National Army Museum Templer Study Centre 6510/146/2/25

properties.Name: Sailor and marine riot
properties.Agents: led by Lieutenant George Frye serving in Jamaica under the command of Sir Chaloner Ogle, Rear Admiral of the Red
properties.Results: Frye court martialled upon the complaint of his ship's captain for failure of discipline and to cause riot and disorder amongst the common sailors and marines
properties.Label: Colony of Jamaica

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: caused by press gang activities
properties.Results: mentioned in correspondence by Grace, Lady Knatchbull, with her son Edward
properties.Label: Kent, England
properties.Archival sources: Kent History and Library Centre U951/C172/2

properties.Name: Battle of Lexington and Concord
properties.Agents: first skirmish of the American Revolution
properties.Label: Lexington, New England

properties.Name: Riot in Thames Street
properties.Agents: William Jones of Manor Place, Walworth, Surrey, who, when helping his relative Captain Donald Cameron to raise an independent company, had been assaulted at the Sir John Falstaff public house in Thames Street [London] by a group of republicans led by Faro, the commander of a West Indiaman, who had uttered sedition against the king.
properties.Results: The landlord had only brought charges of assault and riot in the lord mayor's court but had since agreed with Jones that he had heard the seditious words.
properties.Label: London, England

properties.Name: Crimp Riots
properties.Agents: alarming riot at the White lion, Shoe Lane, Fleet Street, where recruits induced to enlist by crimps are believed to be concealed
properties.Results: riot at Whitcombe Street only suppressed by a significant military presence and the reading of the Riot Act
properties.Label: London, England

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: Concerning behaviour of Robert Booth, Justice of the Peace. On Sunday 8 December 1745, a crowd assembled to fight the rebels [Jacobites].
properties.Results: Hawarth gathered principal inhabitants of the town, who they agreed to supply men with powder and ammunition. Booth believed the Riot Act should be read to crowd; Hawarth urged him not to, but eventually Booth dispersed crowd 'by other means'.
properties.Label: Manchester, Lancashire, England

properties.Name: Nore mutinies
properties.Agents: two mutinies by sailors of the British Royal Navy
properties.Label: Nore, England

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: Riot lead by Matthew Bilton of Kilburn, labourer, within the North Riding had demanded 7 guims (one for each Township) from him at the head of a mob of 100 people firing gums and crying 'No Militia', which he refused to pay except to the Constables.
properties.Results: John Henshaw, servant to Lady Betty Egerton, to give evidence.
properties.Label: North Riding, England
properties.Archival sources: Hertfordshire Archives and Local Studies AH 2161c

properties.Name: Nottingham Militia Riot
properties.Agents: militia riot in Nottingham
properties.Results: riot put down without the assistance of the troops
properties.Label: Nottingham, England

properties.Name: Pennsylvania Line Mutiny / Pennsylvania Winter Mutiny
properties.Agents: mutiny in the American army
properties.Label: Pennsylvania, North America

properties.Name: Militia Riot
properties.Agents: 8 September, 1780, a militia riot at Plymouth
properties.Label: Plymouth, England

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: William Brandon, Portsmouth, to the Victualling Board. The Nassau is to be reduced to a guardship and was paid off, but there were no lists for the short allowance money so a riot ensued, which was controlled by soldiers.
properties.Label: Portsmouth, England

properties.Name: Militia Act Riot
properties.Agents: riot in the parish of Sibsey near Boston, magistrates attributed to riot to "opposition formed in the collier counties against the Militia Act"
properties.Results: request that a small party of soldiers be sent to preserve the peace and protect Joseph Robertson and his house
properties.Label: Sibsey, England

properties.Name: John Hartland Riot
properties.Agents: riot instigated by journeyman brush-maker John Hartland, attack on a "crimping house" (where men are bribed into sailing or army enlistments for drink); rioters gathered all day outside Lowthorpe's house throwing stones and breaking the door down with a tree, burning the contents of the bar and pulling down walls and breaking windows.
properties.Results: John Hartland and James Maxey convicted at the Surrey Lent Assizes in 1796, for rioting at the Obelisk, St. George's Fields, Southwark, and demolishing the tavern house, property of Thomas Lowthorpe, keeper of the Royal George Tavern, on 14 July 1795 [1796?]; Light Horse Guards quelled the riot; grounds for clemency: that Hartland wore different clothes to the man identified as tearing down the tree, that he was in the Circus Tap all evening and was so amazingly drunk that he was incapable of being involved in the riot, that their role in the riot was as a result of too much drink not disaffection to the Crown and the constitution, that they are not members of 'certain Societies' [radical societies]. Initial sentence: death. Recommendation: hesitates to recommend mercy [really addresses the case of Maxey in his recommendation]
properties.Label: St. George's-Fields, Southwark, England

properties.Name: St. George's Fields Massacre
properties.Agents: protest in favour of politician John Wilkes, intervention by Horse Grenadier Guards 3rd regiment of Foot guards
properties.Results: among those tried for the initial riot were Edward TOBIAS and John ROBINSON
properties.Label: St George's Fields, Southwark, in South London

properties.Name: Spithead mutinies
properties.Agents: mutiny by sailors of the British Royal Navy
properties.Label: Spithead, England

properties.Name: Trooper riot
properties.Agents: a riot by the troopers quartered in the town of Stafford
properties.Label: Stafford, England

properties.Name: Riot
properties.Agents: riot that occurred at a sub division meeting for hearing appeals against the new supplementary militia, at Stow on Thursday 8 December 1796. The lists were taken from the constables and torn. Requests that a troop of horse attend at Stow on the Wold on Thursday 29 December 1796, the day fixed for appeals, and business would proceed quietly.
properties.Label: Stow, England

properties.Name: Massacre of Tranent / Tranent Militia Riot
properties.Agents: took place on 29 August 1797 in the town of Tranent, following a proclamation by local people to object to the conscription of Scots into the British Militia
properties.Results: escalated mass protest with heavy casulties
properties.Label: Tranent, East Lothian, Scotland

properties.Name: Yeoman Riot
properties.Agents: Robert Leadam, Thomas Wilkinson of Walkington, et. Al.
properties.Label: Walkington, England

properties.Name: Anticipated riots
properties.Agents: The threatened riot, caused by the distribution of seditious leaflets against recruitment, did not take place.
properties.Results: No interventions necessary.
properties.Label: Wentworth, England

properties.Name: Battle of Rathangan
properties.Agents: in the context of the Irish Rebellion
properties.Results: British victory, rebels repulsed 28 May
properties.Label: Rathangan, County Kildare, Ireland

properties.Name: Logan's Raid
properties.Agents: loyalist / British troops versus patriots
properties.Results: American victory
properties.Label: Mackachack, Ohio
properties.Place (modern): Mackachack, near present West Liberty, Ohio
properties.Historic affiliation: British Empire / United States of America

properties.Name: Gunpowder Incident
properties.Agents: conflict between Lord Dunmore, the Royal Governor, and militia led by Patrick Henry over removal of military supplies
properties.Results: militia companies mustering throughout the colony
properties.Label: Williamsburg, Virginia
